metadata.title: Comparison of diffusion tensor imaging and voxel-based morphometry to detect white matter damage in Alzheimers disease
metadata.abstract: Regional atrophy of gray matter (GM) in Alzheimers disease (AD) is well known; however, the relationship between macroscopic and microscopic changes of cerebral white matter (WM) is uncertain. The aim of this study was to investigate the pattern of GM, WM atrophy, and microscopic WM changes in the same individuals with AD. All subjects (10 AD and 15 healthy controls HC) underwent a MRI scanning at 1.5 T, including a 3-dimensional volumetric scan and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI). We performed statistical parametric mapping (SPM) with DTI to evaluate the patterns of the microscopic WM changes, as well as voxel-based morphometry (VBM) for GM and WM volume changes between patients with AD and HC. GM atrophy was detected, mainly in posterior regions, and WM atrophy was similarly distributed, but less involved on VBM analysis. Unlike WM atrophy on VBM analysis, microscopic WM changes were shown in the medial frontal, orbitofrontal, splenium of the corpus callosum, and cingulum on DTI analysis with SPM. We demonstrated that the pattern of macroscopic WM atrophy was similar to GM atrophy, while microscopic WM changes had a different pattern and distribution. Our findings suggest that WM atrophy may preferentially reflect the secondary changes of GM atrophy, while microscopic WM changes start earlier in frontal areas before GM and WM atrophy can be detected macroscopically.

Introduction.text:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is widely used in studies involving patients with Alzheimers disease (AD) because it can noninvasively quantify gray matter (GM) and white matter (WM) integrity with high reproducibility 1. Voxel-based morphometry (VBM) is a fully automated, objective method of examining voxelbased GM or WM differences across the entire brain in different populations 2,3. Although several studies have reported GM and WM differences between patients with AD and normal controls using VBM 45678910111213, the presence and extent of WM atrophy has not been determined, indicating that macroscopic WM atrophy measured using region of interest or VBM methods does not truly reflect microscopic WM changes. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) has been used to overcome this limitation. The strengths of DTI are that it reflects the size, orientation, and organization of WM tracts non-invasively by measuring the random motion of water molecules as well as it is capable of assessing microstructural properties of WM, which can provide information in addition to macrostructural properties. Moreover, the voxel-based analytic method can also be applied to DTI analysis, and studies have successfully demonstrated regional microscopic alterations of WM in patients with AD 151617.
This study investigated the pattern of GM and WM atrophy in patients with AD using VBM. Furthermore, by using DTI with statistical parametric mapping (SPM), we assessed regional microscopic WM changes and compared WM atrophy and microscopic WM changes in the same individuals simultaneously. We performed this study to examine whether there is an anatomic correspondence between regions of GM atrophy, WM atrophy, and microscopic WM changes.

Participants.text:
Ten patients with mild AD and 15 healthy controls (HC) of comparable age were enrolled. The study was approved by the local ethics committee and informed consent was obtained from all subjects, who were examined using our imaging protocols.
The HC underwent a structured clinical interview to exclude any present or past neuropsychiatric illnesses and abuse of alcohol or drugs, and a physical examination. The cutoff for the Korean version of the Mini-Mental State Examination (K-MMSE) 18 score was set at  27.
All demented patients were diagnosed as probable AD, based on the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke and Alzheimers Disease and Related Disorders Task Force (NINCDS-ADRDA) diagnostic criteria for probable AD 19.

MRI data acquisition.text: All subjects underwent conventional MRI, three-dimensional T1-weighted magnetization prepared rapid gradient echo (MP-RAGE) MRI, and DTI. The MRI was performed on a 1.5 T GE scanner (Signa Excite 11.0; General Electric Medical Systems, Milwaukee, WI, USA). The structural MRI sequences were as follows:  DTI: Approximately 35 axial slices were acquired with a sensitizing gradient (a single b-value of 1000 smm 2 ) along 25 different directions. TR8300 ms, TE81.5 ms, matrix size128128 mm, NEX1, reconstruction matrix  256  256 mm, FOV  260  260 mm, inplane resolution 1.020 1.020, and slice thickness 5 mm with no inter-slice gap.

Imaging processing.text: We used Analyze format images, generated from raw DICOM images using the MRIcro software (http:www.sph.sc.educomd rordenmricro.html). Analyses were run on MATLAB 6.5 (MathWorks, Natick, MA, USA) and using the SPM2 software (Wellcome Department of Imaging Neuroscience, London, UK; http:www.fil.ion.ucl.ac. ukspm).

GM and WM volume analysis.text: Using SPM2, we normalized, segmented, and smoothed all images. We also applied the optimized VBM process described in previous studies to modulate the images 3. First, each native image was registered into the SPM T1 template using a 12-parametric affine transformation 20. Second, all images were normalized spatially using SPM2 built-in routines to compare groups. Third, each normalized image was segmented into GM and WM compartments 2. Fourth, these normalized images, and the GM and WM segments, were smoothed with an isotropic Gaussian kernel of 10 mm full-width-at-halfmaximum (FWHM), to reduce inter-individual gyral variation, and individual global counts were normalized by proportional scaling to a mean value of 5.0. Finally, all smoothed images were averaged in turn to create an SPM T1 template, and GM and WM templates.

DTI analysis.text:
The raw DICOM data were converted into 26 analyze files (e.g., .img or .hdr) by MRIcro. The b0 images of each subject were normalized to a mean T2-template in the SPM2 package using linear steps with 12 degrees of freedom and a 7 mm non-linear warp, and these deformation parameters were applied to the FA and MD images of each subject. The normalized data were then smoothed with a 10 mm FWHM isotropic Gaussian kernel.
We manually measured the area of the lateral and 4th ventricles at the two magnetic resonance slices that showed the maximal ventricular size to correct for size variation in the ventricle.

Statistical analyses.text:
Group statistical analysis was performed using the SPSS software (ver. 12.0 for Windows; SPSS, Chicago, IL, USA). For demographic and clinical data, differences between groups for continuous variables with normal distributions were assessed using Students t-test. For non-parametric data, the Kruskal-Wallis test was used, followed by a retrospective Mann-Whitney U-test or the χ 2 test when appropriate. The significance level was set at P b 0.05.
The normalized MRI TI MP-RAGE and DTI data acquired from HC and AD patients were analyzed by VBM using MATLAB 6.5 and SPM2, which used the framework of the General Linear Model. The DTI, GM, and WM images were analyzed separately. A two-sample t-test was applied to determine significant regional differences between the two subject groups for both GM and WM regions. The ventricle size was entered as a covariate to correct for regional atrophy and head size variation in each subject. The threshold for the results was set at an uncorrected P b 0.001 and an extended threshold of 50 contiguous voxels was applied. The anatomical location of voxels demonstrating a significant difference between the two groups was determined by converting the x, y, and z coordinates for the peak voxel within a cluster from the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) coordinates used in SPM2 analyses, to Talairach coordinates 21 using the MNItoTAL software (http:www.mrc.cbu.cam.ac.ukImagingmnispace.html). The resultant Talairach coordinates were entered into a software program that identifies lobar and Brodman area locations 22.

Results.text: The baseline characteristics of the groups are given in Table 1. There was no significant difference in age, gender, or education between the groups. The K-MMSE score was 20.70  2.36 for the AD patients versus 29.13  8.89 for the HC.

GM volume change.text: The VBM analysis of the regional reduction of GM volume in the AD group, compared with the HC, identified several voxel clusters distributed bilaterally over the temporal and parietal cortices and hippocampi (all significant at the uncorrected P b 0.001 level, onetailed; Fig. 1). The opposite comparison (AD N HC) for GM change showed no voxels at the same threshold.

WM volume change.text: In the WM comparison, regions of significantly decreased WM volume were seen in the left medial temporal region near the hippocampus, parahippocampal gyrus, and left splenium of the corpus callosum (CC; all significant at the uncorrected P b 0.001 level, onetailed; Fig. 1). The opposite comparison (AD N HC) for WM change showed no voxels above the threshold.

Microscopic WM change.text: In the FA analysis, the WM tract densities of the bilateral medial frontal (MF), orbitofrontal (OF), and medial inferior temporal (MIT) areas, splenium of the CC, and posterior cingulum in the AD group were significantly lower than in the HC group (P b 0.001, uncorrected; Fig. 2). Similarly, the differences in MD were distributed relatively more widely in the bilateral MF, OF, MIT, splenium of the CC, and cingulum in the AD group, compared with the HC group (P b 0.001, uncorrected; Fig. 3). Unlike the pattern of volumetric change of the WM in the VBM analysis, the alteration of the microscopic WM density with DTI indicated preferential vulnerability in the anterior (frontal) region as well as the posterior region.

Discussion.text:
This study measured both macroscopic GM and WM atrophy and microscopic WM changes in the same subjects simultaneously. We found that the microscopic WM changes measured by DTI differed in space, that were more widespread than the macroscopic WM changes measured by VBM in patients with AD compared to controls.
GM volume was lost in the bilateral temporoparietal areas and left splenium of the CC, which is a posterior pattern. These findings correspond with those of earlier studies 7,13,14,23, which indicated that the medial and lateral temporal regions were the sites most vulnerable to early involvement and greatest atrophy in patients with AD. When considering the results of the macroscopic WM volume changes, atrophy was evident in the left hippocampus, splenium of the CC, and posterior cingulum; it was similar to the pattern of GM volume loss, but the distribution was smaller and it had a laterality trend (more on the left side), which has been supported in several VBM studies 15,17,242526. It has been suggested that macroscopic WM atrophy results primarily from Wallerian degeneration, secondary to cortical atrophy 24,27, combined with other AD pathology. The selective damage of the WM was probably associated with the deposition of neurofibrillary tangles (NFT) and amyloid plaque in the cortex and among the interconnecting WM fibers. In the presence of GM degeneration, alterations in the quantity of WM likely reflect processes of demyelination and neuronal loss, which will eventually result in macroscopic WM atrophy.
When considering the microscopic WM volume changes seen in the DTI analysis, the regional FA reductions that we found in this study likely reflect WM changes due to the underlying pathological processes, such as demyelination, axonal loss, and amyloid β deposition. Indeed, the FA and MD abnormalities in the DTI analysis were distinct from the WM atrophy on VBM analysis. The FA changes were distributed not only in posterior regions, including the hippocampi and splenium of the CC, but also in anterior regions, such as the MF and OF areas, as seen in previous DTI studies 28,29. Undoubtedly, the FA, MD, and volume change of the WM in the splenium of the CC explained the inter-connection fiber damage secondary to the neuronal damage in the temporo-parietal associative cortices 27. By contrast, the results revealed an incongruence in the frontal region between the macroscopic and microscopic changes in the WM. One explanation for this incongruence may be that regional WM atrophy is secondary to GM volume change, rather than reflecting preceding microscopic WM changes directly. Because DTI is a more sensitive method for detecting WM damage than other MRI images, such as FLAIR or T1, DTI can detect microscopic WM changes that may precede macroscopic WM atrophy in the frontal area. This finding is supported by the frontal hypometabolism seen in 18 F-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) 30313233, high Pittsburgh compound B (PIB) uptake in the frontal area in PIB PET 34, or frontal executive dysfunction in neuropsychological testing in early-stage AD. In other words, the pathology begins in the WM tracts, and that the disconnection between cortical regions is responsible for the reduced glucose uptake. In a previous neuropathological study of AD patients, Braak and Braak demonstrated amyloid β and NFT deposition in the frontal, temporal, and parietal regions, in stages V and VI 35. The WM damage could result from direct damage to the axon caused by NFT deposition within the neurons, or secondary changes of neuronal damage caused by toxic amyloid β deposition outside the neurons, and this may be detected by DTI in the frontal regions before WM atrophy can be detected by VBM analysis.
Some limitations of this study need to be considered. First, the cross-sectional design is a weakness because the decreases in brain structures seen in cross-sectional designs are not the same as longitudinal decreases, and may reflect sampling biases. Second, the sample size is small, so these results need to be interpreted with caution. Third, from a methodological perspective, the template normalization steps result in less precise anatomic specificity than manual tracing 2, especially for very small subcortical structures; however, for many regions that are difficult to trace, VBM provides useful information on both whole-brain and regional GM and WM integrity. The registration of atrophic brains to a standardized template can cause segmentation errors based on a template of normal young brains. We measured the total intracranial volume and lateral and third ventricular areas, which were used as covariates to correct for regional atrophy and size variation of the head. Fourth, because we did not perform tractography or Tract Based Spatial Statistics (TBSS) for minimizing the problem that border voxels can often be included in analyses, one must carefully interpret whether the changes in FA based on a voxel-based comparison are fully representative of the WM tract density. Despite these limitations, a strength of our study was that it measured GM and WM morphometric changes and microscopic alterations of WM concurrently in the same AD participants.
Taken together, the combined VBM and DTI imaging methods could play a significant role in a comprehensive understanding of regional patterns in GM atrophy, and macroscopic and microscopic WM alterations in the same individuals with AD. The patterns of regional GM and WM atrophy are consistent with the current knowledge of the progression of AD pathology, which involves mechanisms of regional brain atrophy, Wallerian degeneration, and brain disconnection. The differences of microscopic WM atrophy in frontal areas between AD patients and controls reflect region-specific degeneration due to the AD process. If adding longitudinal studies, these results may suggest that microscopic WM changes in frontal areas precede macroscopic alterations in the same region, which could reflect functional or metabolic dysfunction in AD. Further longitudinal and pathological research is needed to explore the pattern and the order of WM and GM changes.
